While Tylo is comparable to Kerbin in size and mass, that's where the similarities end. Tylo lacks our crystal clear water and highly breathable air.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Data/F: Samples collected so far have turned out to be an interesting mixture of both rock and ice.
Samples indicate relatively young, volatile ices mixed with a small amount of rock and dust.
The samples we’ve collected are mostly ice mixed with some stone and dust.
Samples are proving to be mostly volatile ices, but with a complex mix of elements.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Sample: Tests indicate a high level of water ice and dark carbonaceous chondrite stone, and surprising amounts of both ferrous and niobium ore.
Tests so far suggest the ice in this area is much younger, in geological terms, than the darker highlands.
Samples are comprised of water ice and frozen CO2, mixed with a surprising amount of crystalized ammonia.
We are detecting ferrous ore, niobium ore, carbonaceous chondrite, frozen CO2 and frozen ammonia as well as minute traces of several other organic compounds. It may take days to identify them all.
Science/Experiments/CrewObservation/Data: The surface below seems dark and mysterious, especially at night.
I can make out vast plateaus and deep, mysterious lowlands in the fractured terrain below.
The surface looks like chocolate but is mostly ice and dirt. I doubt it is yummy.
The ground looks like light colored dirt but is actually ice and snow. It is very strange.
There is something odd about this crater. In some ways it resembles the craters on the Mun and Minmus but is not identical to either.
This crater is so massive; I can’t see both sides at once.
Science/Experiments/OrbitalSurvey/Data/F: The lab is currently investigating Tylo’s massive gravitational pull and its influence on Jool’s other moons.
Science/Experiments/RadiationObservation: Readings are suggesting Tylo has a fairly sizable magnetic field, indicating the presence of a large and molten core.
Science/Experiments/OrbitalSurvey/Data/F: These craters are great and all, but there are so few of them. This surface is very dynamic.
This crater puts Mun's giant rayed crater to shame!
The highlands are nearly 20 degrees colder than the lowlands. It's sweater weather!
Tectonic activity gives this terrain a strange, rippled surface. Landing here would be a unique challenge.
Science/Experiments/OrbitalSurvey/Sample: We are investigating the interactions between Tylo's and Jool's magnetic fields. All of these lines have meaning, I swear!
We are studying the interesting rays extending from these craters. Tylo's strong gravity may lead to equally strong impacts.
Current estimates suggest this crater was made with the force of 100 million Mainsail engines. Can we make a rocket like that?
These highlands are massive ice sheets ranging from one to several kilometers in thickness or more.
It's cold everywhere, but the lowlands are warmer if you're sensitive to the cold.
Science/Experiments/RadiationObservation: We have detected no radioactive hots pots with the exception of a very large crater dubbed “The Dimple”.
There are traces of radiation emanating from the surrounding area. But the absence of any radioactive elements in the ground samples suggests this is likely residual radiation from Jool.
There are only minute traces of residual radiation being detected, suggesting this area is fairly young, in geologic terms.
There is only residual radiation being detected inside the crater.
There is a fairly large amount of gamma radiation being detected inside this crater, suggesting it’s impactor may have contained a considerable amount of uranium-235.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Da: Instruments are detecting no trace of heat or geological activity on Bop. It is quite dead.
Spectral analysis confirms Bop has the lowest albedo of any celestial body in the Kerbolar system.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Sa: Bop has no magnetic field of its own, but Jool still shields it from Kerbol's solar winds. What a good big brother!
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Da: We are currently measuring the size of several large nearby boulders to try and determine their mass and density.
Analysis suggests many of the large boulders in this crater are the remains of the impactor that formed it.
We can observe several distinct layers of Bop from this crater. The lab is analyzing these layers so we can learn about Bop's history.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Sa: Gravimetric instruments show Bop’s gravity is only 6% that of Kerbin. Be careful not to jump too high!
We are currently using carbon dating to try and determine the age of this crater. Data is still incoming, but suggests it is quite ancient.
Using carbon dating, the bottom layer is nearly a billion years older than the uppermost surface of Bop.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Data/F: Samples are mostly composed of organic-rich silicates and carbonaceous chondrites.
Samples are mostly composed of silicon, and what appears to be ice crystals. We will need to analyze these further to determine what this frozen material is.
Like most of Bop samples of the crater floor are mostly composed of organic-rich silicates and carbonaceous chondrites.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Sample: These samples are similar to the rest of Bop, but they are mixed with surprising amounts of ferrous ore and crystalized ammonia particles.
Analysis indicates the samples are composed of carbonaceous chondrites and organic-rich silicates mixed with surprising amounts water ice, frozen CO2, and crystalized ammonia particles.
As well as organic-rich silicates and carbonaceous chondrites, the lab has found large amounts of ferrous ore in these samples, suggesting this crater’s impactor was a heavy iron-nickel asteroid.
Science/Experiments/CrewObservation/Data: Bop looks like a gigantic chocolate ball with a bite taken out of it.
The surface looks dark brown and eerie, even with Kerbol high overhead.
There are gigantic rocks everywhere and I’m feeling quite small.
This crater seems strangely ancient and weathered.
This crater is absurdly huge. Did a giant creature took a bite out of Bop?
Science/Experiments/OrbitalSurvey/Data/F: Was Bop was formed naturally or is a captured D-type asteroid? This lab is taking a long time to find out!
We are mapping staggering number of boulders. Landing would be precarious at best.
We are currently mapping the surface, and incoming data suggests it is rough and uneven. Choose your landing sites carefully.
These samples have ferrous iron and basalt, along with the usual silicate rock and frozen sulfur dioxide ice.
This crater may have been formed by an oblique impact of 30 degrees or less.
Science/Experiments/OrbitalSurvey/Sample: Bop’s orbital inclination may be the result of a massive impact with another rocky body.
We are mapping the thousands of impact craters covering Bop. This is going to take weeks to organize!
We are trying to analyze the craters to see if any came before the giant impact.
Results suggest Bop and the impactor should have been vaporized, but here we are with Bop.
Science/Experiments/RadiationObservation: Bop has no magnetic field to protect it from both Kerbol and Jool.
We have detected no signs of significant radiation on the surface.
While there is residual radiation from both Jool and Kerbol, there are no signs of radioactive elements in the ground samples.
Only residual background radiation here, boss!
There are varying radiation signatures in the layers of exposed rock. We're getting new insights into the intensity of the solar winds that make Bop Bop.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Da: The readings make no sense. Pol should not be this warm. Recalibrating…
We have found no craters on the surface, suggesting Pol’s surface is quite active, despite its small size and extreme distance from Jool.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Sa: Temperature, radiation, surface activity, everything is much higher than expected. Pol is alive!
Readings indicate that despite how far Pol is from Jool, it is deep in Jool's magnetic field.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Da: The surrounding topology is very uneven. Finding a flat spot for future explorers to land safely is proving to be challenging.
The onboard mystery goo appears to be glowing ever so slightly, even though it is a heavily shielded container.
Spectral analysis confirms this terrain is one of the most reflective surfaces in the solar system.
Carbon dating confirms this cryo-volcano is very recent and may have formed within the last 100 years or less.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Sa: Despite conventional wisdom, thermo-analysis confirms the surface of Pol is just slightly above freezing.
Seismometers are detecting faint tremors deep inside Pol, indicating it is still geologically active.
Ground penetrating radar seems to indicate these mountains are very loosely compacted. Possibly formed from the deposits of nearby cryo-volcanoes.
Seismometers are detecting strong tremors in this area and suggest this volcano may erupt again at any time. Extreme caution is advised.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Data/F: Samples contain silicate rock and sulfur dioxide ice.
Samples appear to be mostly silicate rock with traces of metallic ores
Samples are comprised of mostly sulfur dioxide ices and other organic elements.
Samples contain silicate rock and frozen sulfur dioxide.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Sample: Along with silicate rock and sulfur dioxide ice, we are detecting ferrous iron and basalt.
Samples appear to be mostly silicate rock mixes with minute amounts of ferrous ore and traces of both uranium-238 and thorium-235.
Analysis shows these samples contain roughly 93% sulfur dioxide ice, 5 % frozen CO2 and crystalized ammonia, as well as trace amounts of several other organic elements.
These are some of the most complex samples collected on Pol, comprised of silicate rock, sulfur dioxide ice, crystalized CO2 and ammonia, as well as trace amounts of both uranium-238 and thorium-235.
Science/Experiments/CrewObservation/Data: I can’t decide what Pol most resembles: custard, caramel, or butter.
From here the surface reminds me of some places I read about in children’s stories… And none of them were nice.
Everything is orange colored. I’ve never seen anything like it.
This has to be the weirdest colored terrain I’ve ever seen. Words cannot describe how strange everything looks.
I feel like I’m standing on the largest mound of orange Sherbet in the universe.
This is the strangest volcano I’ve ever seen. How can a volcano eject snow?
Science/Experiments/OrbitalSurvey/Data/F: The lab has mapped several large volcanic cones but cannot confirm if they are still active or not. Caution is highly advised.
Surface mapping indicates almost no craters. Pol must have a very dynamic surface.
Minor fluctuations in temperature seem to coincide with the various surface colors, but we have no explanation for this phenomenon.
Surface mapping shows a smooth, almost melted mountain topography. This is unlike anything we’ve ever seen.
There is no evidence of current activity but mind your lander if you decide to visit the volcanoes!
Science/Experiments/OrbitalSurvey/Sample: We have theory that Pol’s core contains large amounts of uranium-238 and thorium-232. Could this explain how and why Pol’s core is so hot?
We are detecting several areas of increased temperature on the surface. There is no evidence of volcanic activity, but that doesn't mean some is impending.
Laser mapping discovered several areas resembling lava flows. Landing conditions should be favorable but be on the lookout for volcanic activity.
These mountains were likely formed by tectonic activity, and that would suggest several tectonic plates covering the surface.
We are detecting heat blooms around the larger volcanoes. Despite Pol’s small size, this is a strong indicator of subsurface magma pools.
Science/Experiments/RadiationObservation: We are detecting a faint magnetic field surrounding Pol. Impossible as it sounds, this suggests Pol’s core is at least partially comprised of molten iron.
Radiation signatures suggest an unusually high amounts of both uranium-238 and thorium-232.
There is a considerable amount of radiation in this area. Prolonged exposure is not recommended.
Instruments are detecting considerable amounts of gamma radiation. Iodine pills are recommended before venturing outside the ship.
Like most of Pol, there is a considerable amount of gamma radiation being detected on these mountains, as well as solar radiation from Kerbol.
This is one of the most radioactive areas on Pol. Prolonged exposure could prove harmful or even fatal, even with a protective spacesuit.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Da: There are no signs of any direct or induced magnetic field being generated, suggesting Eeloo’s core is solid and cold.
Spectro-analysis confirms Eeloo has the highest albedo of any planet in the Kerbolar system.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Sa: Thermal imaging indicates the surface is frigid. Average daily temperatures are between -220°C and -240°C.
Current measurements confirm Eeloo has an eccentricity of 0.26 and an inclination of 6.15°. We have a whiteboard full of guesses as to why.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Da: Temperatures here are averaging -225 degrees Celsius. Even the mystery goo is shivering.
Visual analysis confirms this icy crater is one of the most reflective surfaces ever discovered.
We are currently carbon dating some of the rock samples collected to try and determine when this canyon was formed.
Measurements confirm this is the largest canyon in the entire solar system.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Sa: Ground penetrating radar suggests this ice sheet is hundreds of kilometers thick.
Standard carbon dating techniques are useless in this icy crater, but the smoothness suggests Kerbol’s solar winds have been slowly eroding it over thousands if not millions of years.
The lab is taking very precise measurements at specific points along the canyon walls. Over time these will help determine if the canyon walls are expanding or contracting or fixed in position.
Seismometers are not detecting any tremors or other vibrations, suggesting this is rift not tectonic in nature. But we will need more data over time to confirm.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Data/F: The ice is extremely hard and makes collecting samples difficult. But what we have collected so far seems to be mostly composed of frozen nitrogen with other exotic ices.
Samples are comprised of mostly frozen nitrogen, frozen carbon monoxide, frozen carbon dioxide, but also contain a large quantity of organic chemicals.
Samples are a mix of nitrogen ice and carbonaceous rock.
Tests indicate samples from the bottom of this rift are mostly carbonaceous mudstone and shale.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Sample: Ice samples contain mostly frozen nitrogen, frozen carbon monoxide, frozen carbon dioxide and frozen methane with traces of water ice and other organic chemicals.
Tests indicate a high amount of organic chemicals like methanol, hydrogen cyanide, formaldehyde, ethanol, ethane, and even some amino acids, suggesting the impactor may have been a cometary fragment.
Samples are comprised of frozen nitrogen, frozen carbon monoxide, frozen carbon dioxide mixed with carbonaceous mudstone and shale.
These samples are mostly comprised of carbonaceous mudstone and shale with traces of granite and basalt and some organic compounds.
Science/Experiments/CrewObservation/Data: It’s strange that Eeloo looks nothing like the artist’s renditions we saw in school.
That’s supposed to be ice down there, but it has an odd sort of greenish color. I like it.
Everything is solid ice. I told R&D we should have ice-skates built into our spacesuits. Maybe next time they’ll listen to me.
This icy crater is like a gigantic glass bowl. Just imagine how many snacks it could hold!
Is this a crack or a canyon? Or both? Does that make it a crack-on? (See what I did there?)
The walls are so steep and high it would be impossible to reach the top without a jet pack.
Science/Experiments/OrbitalSurvey/Data/F: The lab is currently mapping the thousands of impact craters but has found nothing even remotely large enough to cause the massive cracks in Eeloo’s icy surface. We will continue to investigate.
These are some of the largest and deepest canyons ever discovered. Don't fall in!
There are many large craters, but Mun easily has it beat.
Laser mapping confirms this to be the largest canyon in the system.
According to long range imaging, the surface is solid ice, not snow. We’ll need more data before we can determine if it makes good ice cream.
Science/Experiments/OrbitalSurvey/Sample: The lab is investigating a coffee-fueled hypothesis by Keri Kerman that the merger of two uranium-rich plumes within Eeloo’s mantle caused the interior to heat and expand, cracking its icy surface.
Thermal imaging indicates the canyon bottoms are 20 degrees colder than the rest of the planet. Since there are no heat signatures, we presume these canyons are not volcanic or tectonic in nature.
The craters we’ve mapped are large but shallow. Based on our findings, impactors may have been icy comets and not harder rock asteroids.
All data confirms this to be the largest, deepest, and steepest canyon ever discovered. But we are at a loss how it was formed.
Tests confirm this area is the most reflective surface ever discovered. They were polished by Kerbol’s solar winds over billions of years.
Science/Experiments/RadiationObservation: There is very little radiation being detected on the surface. But we are gathering some excellent data on the solar winds this far from Kerbol.
We are picking a slightly higher radiation signature near the great rift than the rest of Eeloo.
There is almost no radiation coming from the ice. What little we can detect is likely residual and solar or cosmic in origin.
There is almost no surface radiation being detected inside this crater.
There is slight increase in radiation along the floor of this canyon.
We are detecting a slight increase in radiation compared to the rest of Eeloo. Signatures indicate the presence of uranium-238, although we have found none in the local ground samples.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Da: Normally, this rock would be a sign of tectonic activity, but Bop does not rock and roll.
There are no other fossils here. It must have been so lonely.
We can find no unusual readings in any test to suggest how these stones are moving.
Tests confirm the double arch is faintly magnetic! Let me put my "Duna is for lovers" magnet on it.
All readings match the surrounding area, so we'll have to find another way to determine how this formation was created.
There are no strange readings. All tests are nominal. It's so quiet. I don’t like it.
The wind completely stopped near the monument. Monument, are you haunted?
The surrounding area is so windy that it can easily whip the dust around. Did the wind and dust carve this feature?
Nothing unusual here, beyond this really cool rock!
The area is brutally cold, but there is no evidence of any other formation besides this wave.
Surrounding terrain is much like the rest of Eve: volcanic rock and ash.
The surrounding area is much like the rest of Eve. Temperature, barometric pressure, solar radiation all within expected parameters.
The surrounding area is quite windy. We are clocking gusts of almost 25 kph.
All readings are within expected parameters. At least this rock isn't scary!
The surrounding area is similar to the rest of Gilly. There is no evidence of how this formation came to be.
The area surrounding this massive formation may be a recent lava plain.
Tests indicate this whole area is a vast, recently-cooled volcanic plain!
Instruments show wind speeds under 5 kph. It's so serene. It may be one of the top five nap spots.
The surrounding area is quite lovely. No unusual readings indicated.
Air samples are surprisingly pure. Do you think we could pump this into the cursed restroom at the Research and Development Center?
The air is crisp and cold. Temperatures fall as we climb higher.
Temperature is average for this time of year, which is all of the year.
Instruments are not picking up anything unusual here.
Temperature and barometric pressure all align with most of Laythe.
There are many other signs of extinct life here, including shell and bone fragments. There are no signs of living life here. I'm not sure that's a bad thing.
The area consists of rolling hills of glass sand with some small glass fragments. Instruments are picking up nothing unusual.
We cannot find any evidence of the monument’s construction. Whoever built this is just as skilled at cleaning up as they are at building.
Samples of the surrounding area suggest this rock is part of a massive lava field.
We can find little evidence explaining this strange crystal formation, but it is shiny.
The area around is scattered with the exact same kind of rock and stone, but this rock is an outlier.
There is absolutely nothing out of the ordinary about the surrounding area. All readings are normal.
The area around this rocky mound is covered in large and small basalt rocks.
We can detect nothing out of the ordinary in this area. Oh, except for the arch.
We can find no reason anyone would want to land here.
Data suggests the area has been volcanically active recently. Be ready to evacuate at a moment’s notice. No one likes a cooked Kerbal.
This area was volcanically active in the last few years.
There are no unusual readings, but the mystery goo is squirming around like it’s trying to find something.
We are picking up what appears to be a faint radio signal. Is it coming from the monument, or is it some other natural source?
This rock formation’s strange position is likely the result of glacial movement of Tylo’s surface.
We have not detected any unusual readings so far. We'll need a different experiment to determine the formation of this amazing structure.
The survey did not give us any new information about this scary cave, so I'm just going to say it's haunted.
We can confirm that this is the tallest ice structure on Vall. Take a picture!
Instrument readings are all normal for Eve. Temperature is 148.5°C. Barometric pressure at 3.9. On the bright side, there is a steady breeze blowing from the southwest.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Sa: Measurements confirm this is one of the largest boulders on Bop.
We have found no evidence of other kraken, a ship, or anything to help explain how this creature came to be on Bop.
Data suggests that the surface of Bop is moving under these stones. Do you think Bop will be mad if we take one of the stones?
Data suggests this formation was once a massive tower that collapsed under its own mass.
There are signs of water erosion, but we're not positive that is how these rocks were formed.
The mystery goo is acting strange again. It is trying to mimic the Duna face, but the eyes are all wrong.
One of the branches of this amazing monument appears to be broken, but we cannot find where it is. We even used ground penetrating radar!
We are picking up some of the highest recorded wind gusts on Duna here, reaching nearly 100 kph!
Incoming data suggests this was result of a huge asteroid impact throwing this single chunk of ice kilometers high. That's precision!
There are a few guesses as to what made this ice sheet, including tidal forces or a frozen impact. Can you get us more data?
Barometric pressure is nearly 4 times as dense as Kerbin. That's strangely normal for Eve.
We are considerably north of the equator. Temperatures in this area are brutally hot, reaching as high as 139°C.
Evidence suggests this formation is the result of countless eons of wind erosion slowly wearing it away.
We can find no evidence in the surrounding area to explain this incredible formation.
The formation itself is slightly hotter than the surrounding terrain, suggesting absorbs and retains heat from Kerbol.
Testing suggests this entire area, including Rock 772-024J, was the result of substantial volcanic activity within 1000 years.
We can find no evidence of other volcano tubes matching this impressive structure on Ike.
Temperatures and humidity are all perfect, but the barometric pressure is falling slightly. There might be a brief shower later!
We are observing the wind patterns swirling around the upper portions of the tower.
This area is pristine, but we have experienced some extremely low temperatures at night. Luckily, we brought self-heating snacks!
Instruments indicate a drop in oxygen near the peak. Spacesuits may be needed.
Temperature, barometric pressure, and humidity is all nominal. Wind speeds are low. It is a perfect day for flying or sitting under a tree with a good book. Maybe both at the same time.
There is an unusual lack of wildlife near the pyramid. Instruments are detecting nothing out of the ordinary, but it's so quiet.
It is theorized these ball rocks formed when very small minerals cement sediment around a stone or a piece of shell.
Samples are covered with several millimeters of caked sea salt. We have a prize for whoever licks it first.
We are taking measurements to verify a hypothesis that both pieces of this formation were fragments of a large impact that rolled downhill, and one landed on top of the other.
There are no signs of chisel marks, laser burns, or anything else to indicate how this was carved. We even broke out the microscope!
According to thermal scans, the surface of that rock is almost 100°C. It could melt right through your glove.
Scans verify the walls of the Mohole formation are nearly vertical. If this is some sort of volcanic vent, it does not explain the crystal core. We will continue to investigate.
Survey data suggests this formation may be a gigantic fragment from a past asteroid impact that landed upright. Was the universe playing lawn darts?
Ground penetrating radar cannot determine how deep this goes.
This area was once volcanically active. This monstrous rock could have been a product of an eruption in the Mun’s past.
Seismometers suggest this arch extends far underground, but we have not determined if this is an arch or a full ring
Clearly someone else was here, but the footsteps trail off and end. We can find no evidence of a rescue. What happened?
Seismometers are picking up intermittent tremors, which is to be expected. The mystery goo seems nervous.
Test results suggest this strange object is hollow. Is it a gigantic bubble?
We have detected no tectonic activity or found any evidence that would explain why this rock is protruding so far above the surface of Tylo.
The incoming data is conflicted. This monument is much older than the ground it is standing on.
If our measurements are correct, a rover hitting this formation at the correct speed should be able to do a complete 360-degree roll before crashing back to the ground. Let's try it!
There is little evidence in the area to explain this strange rock’s origin. How was it cracked in half?
Data confirms that the scary cave’s “teeth” are massive icicles.
Instruments confirm this area reaches frigid temperatures at night. This ice formation is nearly as hard as steel! I would not recommend building a rocket from it.
Microscopic analysis confirms this formation’s smooth surface is from eons of wind erosion.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Da: Atmospheric pressure increases exponentially the lower we descend. If we dive too deep, we’ll be crushed like an egg!
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Sa: The pressure on Jool is so extreme that its core might be composed of metallic hydrogen.
We are trying to map cloud layers, but there are so many layers! There may be no surface, but we also can't discern the structure of Jool's core.
We're flying through a vast sea of green. I’ve never seen anything this magnificent.
Science/Experiments/AtmosphereSurvey/Sam: We are measuring wind velocities nearing 600 kph in the lower atmosphere. Try not to dip that low, unless you want to be sheared apart.
While there is no visual evidence, we detected strong electrical discharges deeper in the atmosphere. Be advised, your ship is an excellent lightning rod.
The pressure below us is nearly 10 times that of Kerbin. I wouldn't go lower if you like your current shape.
We have discovered bands of slightly slower clouds. They are in excess of 400 kph, but it's still slower!
We are currently observing several large storm systems in this area. Some are massive, larger than the entire planet of Kerbin!
Science/Experiments/AtmosphereSurvey/Dat: Wind speeds lower in the atmosphere are some of the highest ever recorded in the system.
Data suggests a series of severe magnetic storms are running along this band of Jool.
We've gone through five barometers trying to measure the atmospheric pressure here.
For some reason, wind speeds inside this area of clouds are slightly less than the rest of Jool.
We are observing several swirling clouds. They are quite beautiful, but incoming data suggest they are also quite deadly.
Science/Experiments/MarineSurvey/Sample/: Instruments have detected no signs of life. Nothing could exist in this extremely cold water.
The Well may be our best sign that there is a vast ocean stretching endlessly under Vall’s ice.
Science/Experiments/OrbitalSurvey/Sample: Despite its immense size and mass, analysis suggests Jool's density is less than a tenth of Kerbin's.
There are several distinct air currents flowing around Jool. Each one has a different temperature and speed, but they also stay consistent.
The wind speeds swirling around the polar region are so extreme that they cause several vast, hurricane-like storms. Each one measures hundreds, even thousands of kilometers across.
We are observing some minute but interesting variations in radiation coming from Jool. The reason is still unknown, but we suspect Jool’s strange cloud layers.
Jool’s belts move at different speeds, some even seemingly going in reverse to others. We can't wait to find out why!
Science/Experiments/OrbitalSurvey/Data/F: Jool’s mass is nearly twice that of all the other planets in the system--combined!
We are mapping several large bands of varying temperature in an attempt to understand Jool’s jet streams.
The storm systems circling Jool's north pole are fascinating. We could spend days gathering data.
We brought all of the green color chips we could find at the VAB to define every color we see in Jool's cloud belts.

We were able to observe a meteor entering Jool’s atmosphere. The clouds broke and the temperature rose, but within minutes all went back to normal. We had to review footage three times to confirm it even happened.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Data/F: Samples contain much more nickel and ferrous ore than the surrounding terrain.
Microscopic analysis confirms this carcass is completely fossilized. Don't chip your teeth!
Samples of the rock are mostly carbonaceous chondrite.
Samples match the surrounding rocks and boulders.
The composition of these rocks is the same as the others on Duna, but we don't know how these got their shape.
The Duna face is made of volcanic basalt covered in a thick layer of reddish dust. Nothing unique here about the composition.
While this monument looks like a tree, it is the same volcanic basalt found on much of Duna.
The rock samples we’ve collected suggest the top of this structure is volcanic basalt atop a softer sandstone. Maybe that explains how it eroded into its present form.
Samples suggest the captured ice piece is slightly different in composition from the ice cliff it is trapped in.
Samples collected show this ice sheet to be nearly pure frozen water ice.
The surrounding terrain has a higher concentration of ferrous ore than most of the planet.
Like much of Eve, this island seems comprised of volcanic rock. The shape is unlike any volcanic vent or impact crater we've found.
The surrounding terrain is a mixture of basalt and nickel iron.
The terrain is normal for Gilly: mostly iron and nickel with traces of granite and some silicates.
Samples show an elevated concentration of ferrous iron.
Samples of Rock 772-024J seem to match the other surrounding rocks and boulders.
Samples show the Giant’s Linguini is similar to the surrounding basalt rocks, but it is far older.
The area is mostly sand and dirt.
Data suggests this tower is ancient volcanic basalt.
The snow and ice samples are almost free of impurities. Down the hatch for science!
Samples gathered from the summit are mostly hard granite.
Samples gathered around the KSC are dirt, small pebbles, and some interesting leaves that might make a pretty display.
Samples indicate the pyramid is made up of immense limestone blocks. It is unknown how our fore-Kerbals moved such massive objects.
Samples are a combination of calcium and sandstone layers that were built up over thousands of years.
Samples have confirmed this skeleton is still bone, not fossilized minerals. Laythe’s extinction event happened only recently, and by recently, I mean geologically recently.
Samples are comprised of silicon and shocked quartz.
Samples indicate the monument to be made of one gigantic piece of Minmus silicon glass, but we have not located anything that resembles an excavation site.
Samples suggest this formation is volcanic in nature. No surprise there.
This core is surprisingly hard. We shattered several hammers to obtain a small sample.
The ground samples near this giant rock are almost pure basalt.
There is nothing abnormal to report about the samples collected.
Samples are basalt with some small iron stones mixed in.
We have not been able to obtain a sample from this arch. Whatever it is made of, we can't break it off into our tubes.
We have found little scraps of stuff on the ground, but there is nothing that would indicate who is or what befell the pilot.
This tower is layers of sulfur dioxide ices built up over time. It's an excellent example of a small volcano.
Samples match the surrounding terrain.
This rock is the same dark carbonaceous chondrite stone as the rest of Tylo’s highlands.
The monument is carved of the same rocky material found on Tylo’s highlands.
Samples indicate this rock to be a type of carbonaceous chondrite stone, similar to Tylo’s highland region.
Samples contain large amounts of nickel and ferrous ore. That may indicate it was an impactor fragment.
Samples are an exact match to the surrounding snow and ice.
Samples have determined this formation to be nearly pure water ice.
This formation’s purple color is a result of iodine in the atmosphere staining the surface.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Sample: Samples show a high degree of nickel and ferrous ore in the balancing rock, suggesting it may be an impactor fragment. The odds of it landing the way it has are astronomical.
Carbon dating suggests this fossilized beast is several million years old.
Samples of the surrounding terrain have detected carbonaceous chondrites, organic-rich silicates, and a surprising amount of water ice.
Results indicate the double arch is almost pure metallic iron with traces of nickel and lithium ore.
There is evidence of both water and wind erosion in the samples we’ve gathered. Which one was the driving force in forming these strange rocks?
Observations of the rock surface show no visible markings, even on a microscopic level. If it was carved, the chisel marks may have been eroded by the constant wind.
We carefully scraped some samples from the monument’s ornaments, and the tests verified they are gold and turquoise. Gold and turquoise are not native to Duna.
Test results, including microscopic analysis, confirm this structure is a result of wind erosion, not a part of some ancient ocean.
Sample results show the captured ice piece to have a more frozen carbon dioxide than the nearby cliff. It's not a shard of the cliff.
It is hard to put a date on something like this, but data suggest this ice formation would take millions of years of exposure to solar radiation to become as smooth as it is.
Samples of the frog rock show it to be comprised of mostly volcanic basalt. Maybe it's the shattered remains of an immense lava bomb.
Samples are volcanic basalt and ferrous iron, and the heart lake is almost pure liquid sulfur.
The samples of the tessellated pavement are nearly pure basalt. They're likely the remains of an ancient volcanic field.
The giant rock is composed of granite, which does nothing to explain how it ended up this way.
This formation is nearly pure nickel iron. It may be a massive ejecta from some long past impact.
Samples of Rock 772-024J are comprised of volcanic basalt. It's geologically a baby.
This giant lava tube is significantly older than the surrounding lava plain. It likely toppled over from its own mass when it was molten and soft.
Samples taken from Kapy Rock are a type of pink sandstone.
This tower is an ancient volcanic tube, and the volcano itself eroded eons ago. We are still trying to determine its exact age.
This glacier is slowly moving at a rate of 5-6 meters per year, like my first rover.
Samples are mostly granite and marble with some surprising traces of volcanic basalt.
The ground samples are fertilized loam, small pebbles, and a chunk of asphalt. Tarmac Henry is going to be furious.
Collective data suggests this pyramid may be nearly 1000 years old!
Microscopic analysis suggests the ball rocks' spherical shapes are a result of centuries of water and wind erosion gently polishing them smoother than Bob's head. Or Bill's head.
Data is still incoming, but results suggest this skeleton is approximately 1000 years old. This would mean Laythe had life in its oceans until only a millennia ago.
We carefully removed a small sample from both rocks and have determined them to be 99% silicon, plus or minus 1%.
While the monument is made of the same silicon found on Minmus, the crystals may be an undiscovered element! We'll run a poll on the fridge to name it.
This formation to be mostly basalt and similar in appearance to pillow lava. There's no water, so how did this wind up here?
Samples verify the core to be almost pure carbon. In short, it is the largest diamond ever discovered. Mission Control immediately classified this information as super-duper secret.
Samples from the giant ogre formation are nearly pure basalt. Is this huge rock a massive lava bomb?
Samples of the arch are almost pure basalt, but there is no other volcanic formation like this ever discovered or recorded.
Samples of this rock formation are basalt with trace amounts of nickel. This suggests it was formed through volcanic activity and is not an impact ejecta.
The arch is too hard to break a piece off to examine. What tests we can run confirm this arch is comprised of a new element.
Instruments indicate the crashed ship is out of fuel. The fact that it is mostly intact suggests the pilot almost made it to the ground.
Test results show the plume rising from this formation to be nearly pure sulfur dioxide. Do not open the sample container inside the capsule. The rotten egg smell will never come out.
This object is mostly sulfur dioxide ice. This is another indication it may be a gigantic frozen bubble. Is Pol snoring?
Sample analysis confirms this formation’s strange tunnel is a natural crevasse in the rock. It is not the result of erosion, like the caves on Kerbin.
The monument is carved from dark carbonaceous chondrite stone, but we have not been able to gather a sample from the orbs. They are harder than our industrial grade spork.
Curious, tests suggest this rock is much older than the surface terrain around it. It is an interesting clue into Tylo’s strange geology.
Microscopic analysis confirms this rock's strange split is a natural crack, possibly caused by rapid deep freezing after its impact.
Samples taken from the cave floor are mostly frozen water and carbon dioxide with traces of organic chemicals.
Microscopic analysis has confirmed the edges of this formation to be the sharpest natural object ever discovered. One wrong move could easily slice your suit.
Tests confirm this formation to be volcanic basalt matching the surroundings. It is theorized to be the largest ejecta on Eve.
Science/Experiments/CrewObservation/Data: It looks like a computer monitor, but it's the size of a large building. I wonder what it is thinking about.
There can be no doubt now that Kraken are real. Why do they have to be so huge?
There is clearly a trail behind this rock, but I don't see the rock moving.
This double arch is fascinating. Dres, you never fail to impress.
I remember reading about places like this when I was young. I don’t think I ever want to leave.
This strange face looks like it was constructed from stone blocks. There's no way this is a natural formation.
This monument looks like it has been sleeping for eons. Let it continue its nap.
It looks like a giant mushroom. I think I’m going to build my retirement colony at the top of this!
I have never seen a single piece of ice that big. It reminds me of an iceberg back home.
This is in my top ten frozen ice slides.
If you look at it from just the right angle, this rock looks like a gigantic frog.
There is something romantic about a giant purple heart. I wonder if tourists will visit.
This reminds me of the VAB parking lot before the Great Repavement.
I’m afraid that if I touch it, the whole thing will fall over!
I don’t understand how it could be perched upright like that. My legs would get tired.
It looks like a giant turtle or a lawn chair, depending on where you stand. I understand why this rock formation doesn't have a name.
It looks like a gigantic handful of linguini and a most excellent rover ramp!
The Kerbin Kapybara Society is going to lose their collective minds when they see this!
This is the best spot on the planet to go stargazing, if you can find a way to get to the top.
I wonder if we can make snow cones from the glacier ice!
It’s like standing on top of the world, even if you’re not at the top!
There is no place like home.
There is a feeling of awe and wonder surrounding this place. It is truly a marvel.
Mission Control will hate me if I write this on the official report, but they look like beach balls.
The scientists back home have already named this thing a Megalofishicus Rex. As far as I’m concerned, it’s a sea serpent.
I need to be really careful not to tip this amazing rock formation over. Mission Control would cut me to half snack rations for the rest of my life!
It is now clear that we are not alone. What is this creature? It is not Kerbal, nor is it kraken. Who were the builders of this strange and beautiful monument?
Mission Control, you are not going to believe this. It looks like a giant croissant!
It is like a diamond! I can't even describe all the colors I'm seeing within.
I know it sounds odd, but this formation is looking right at me.
It’s hard to believe this formed naturally.
I think you could fit a KSC parking garage in this!
The jewels seem to represent our system! Are those kraken running up the sides? What is this thing?
I thought we were the first to land here, but we are not the first. Oddly, Mission Control can find no record of a landing.
This is the closest I’ve ever been to an active vent. It is a little inspiring and a little scary.
It looks like a giant bubble that froze before it could burst. Where's my giant needle?
There is something mysterious about this rock formation. What secrets does it hold?
In a strange way, this creature seems cheerful. I wonder if it wants my snacks?
I know I’ll get into a lot of trouble, but I really want to use this rock for a rover ramp!
I’m not sure why, but this split rock reminds me of a hoagie. Maybe I’m just hungry. I hope we packed hoagies!
I don’t care if Mission Control promises me a lifetime supply of snacks, I am not going into that cave!
This massive ice structure looks sharp and dangerous. I'm going to take a few steps back.
This is so much fun to climb up and around, but it’s really hot. That might be good for my back!
We're flying through a vast sea of green. I’ve never seen anything this magnificent.
Science/Experiments/RadiationObservation: We have detected no unusual radiation signatures coming from this rock formation.
There is a strange radiation signature coming from this fossil. Keep a safe distance.
There are no unusual radiation signs detected from these remarkable stones.
We have detected faint traces of high-band radiation. Levels are extremely low, so it should not be a risk.
There is little radiation being detected. Even the residual radiation seems lower than average.
There is faint residual radiation being detected, but it matches the surrounding terrain.
There is no unusual radiation coming from the monument. Phew!
There is an increase in residual radiation at the top of this massive structure. The height increases its exposure to Kerbol.
There is no radiation coming from the captured ice fragment.
There is no discernable radiation coming from this ice formation.
There is a slight increase in radiation coming from the frog rock. Maybe it's hiding some uranium.
There is a slight increase in residual radiation coming from the lake itself.
We are reading some residual radiation, but it's nothing out of the ordinary for Eve.
There is only residual solar radiation coming from this incredible rock formation.
Radiation is higher than normal, but we cannot determine the source.
There is no unusual radiation coming from this gigantic rock formation.
There is a faint amount of radiation coming from the Giant’s Linguini. It may contain a minute amount of uranium or thorium.
There are no unusual radiation readings coming from Kapy Rock. We can stay here all day.
There are traces of radiation in areas of the tower. It is likely this massive structure contains some trace, safe amounts of uranium.
There is a slight trace of radiation in the surface ice. That's like residual solar radiation from constant exposure to Kerbol.
The higher we climb, the higher the solar radiation gets.
Radiation levels are within expected levels.
There is a faint radiation signature coming from the pyramid. That is likely residual radiation from exposure to Kerbol over several centuries.
Like most everything on Laythe, the ball rocks are emitting sizable amounts of radiation. Taking one home as a souvenir is out of the question.
There is a high radiation signature coming from this skeleton. That's likely from the salt layer covering it.
There is no unusual radiation being detected around this formation.
There is a faint radiation signature coming from the glowing crystals, but it does not match any known radioactive element or isotope.
We are picking up some significant radiation signatures. Odds are it is from the constant exposure to Kerbol’s fierce solar radiation.
There is significantly less radiation here than on the surface. Perhaps a hole this deep is shielded from most of Kerbol’s solar radiation.
There are no unusual radiation signatures coming from this formation.
There is a small amount of residual solar radiation being emitted from the arch.
There is a slight amount of radiation being detected. We're not sure if this is residual or if there's radioactive material here.
There is absolutely no radiation emanating from this strange arch.
We are picking up solar and residual radiation from Kerbol, but there is nothing unusual about the crashed ship.
We are picking up significant radiation from the tower. Maintain a safe distance.
There is an alarming amount of radiation coming from this formation. Keep the gloves on.
There is a small amount of radiation being detected. That's likely residual radiation from Jool.
We are detecting faint radiation from the glowing orbs, but the signature is strange. We don't know what these orbs are.
There is unusual radiation coming from this rock formation.
We have not detected any unusual radiation levels coming from this formation.
There is no discernable radiation coming from this strange structure.
We are detecting a faint amount of residual radiation coming from this beautiful crystal formation.
There is a slight amount of gamma radiation being detected, but there is no radioactive material in our samples.
Radiation increases drastically the lower we descend. Use extreme caution.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Da: The surrounding area is mostly calcium carbonate with scatted iron fragments.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Sa: Seismic analysis suggests much of this object is buried deep underground. We're only looking at the tip of the object.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Data/F: Fascinating. Samples of this object do not match the surroundings.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Sample: Samples are nearly pure nickel ore, suggesting it may be a large impact fragment.
Science/Experiments/CrewObservation/Data: It looks like a giant fish fin swimming through the ocean.
Science/Experiments/RadiationObservation: There is slight radiation coming from this object that does not match the surrounding terrain. Another hint that it may be an asteroid fragment.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Da: There is heat bloom coming from the center of the lake, rising into the atmosphere.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Sa: Data suggests this lake was formed by a small but powerful impact.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Data/F: This sample has the highest salt content on Laythe.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Sample: There appear to be organic chemicals in our water samples, but there are no signs of life.
Science/Experiments/CrewObservation/Data: I think the Kerbal Tourist Society would be interested in this location if it wasn’t so radioactive.
Science/Experiments/RadiationObservation: We are detecting dangerously high amounts of radiation coming from the center of the lake. There may be a large amount of uranium-238 at the bottom.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Da: This structure is mostly calcium carbonate with small, scattered iron fragments.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Sa: Seismic analysis suggests this to be a single calcium carbonate boulder jutting out from the hillside.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Data/F: Samples of this object are an exact match to the surrounding terrain.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Sample: Samples indicate this object is nearly pure calcium carbonate. The density is higher than expected.
Science/Experiments/CrewObservation/Data: This is such an awesome ramp. Mission Control is going to hate me for this, but I need to try it as soon as possible!
Science/Experiments/RadiationObservation: There is no discernable radiation coming from this amazing formation.
